descript.abstract: This dataset was developed by clipping the FDOT_Monroe_Original_Roads dataset with a polygon dataset from the UF GeoPlan Sea Level Scenario Sketch Planning tool that contains elevations of 4 inches (above NAVD) and lower in Monroe County, FL. The spatial extent of road centerlines in this feature dataset represents areas that would be predicted to flood during the mean highest high tides observed each day under 3 inches of sea level rise. The elevation surfaces were developed using a 5-meter horizontal resolution and LiDAR-based Digital Elevation Model (DEM). More information on inundation surface development for the Sea Level Scenario Sketch Planning tool can be found at: http://sls.geoplan.ufl.edu
descript.purpose: This dataset provides a spatial extent of road centerlines in Monroe County, Florida that overlap with digital elevation model (DEM) heights of 3 inches above MHHW or lower, as identified through the UF GeoPlan Sea Level Scenario Sketch Planning Tool. This height of 3 inches corresponds to the Low range of sea level rise projected for 2030 by the Southeast Florida Regional Climate Compact. The dataset was developed in 2014 at Stetson University and the University of Georgia Carl Vinson Institute of Government through the GreenKeys! planning process, as sponsored by Monroe County's Sustainability Program.

idinfo.useconst: Original data for the FDOT roads dataset include the following text: "This product has been compiled from the most accurate source data from the Florida Department of Transportation's Transportation Statistics Office. However, this product is for reference purposes only and is not to be construed as a legal document or survey instrument. Any reliance on the information contained herein is at the user's own risk. The Florida Department of Transportation assumes no responsibility for any use of the information contained herein or any loss resulting therefrom."The Centerline dataset from the Monroe County Property Appraiser contained no metadata at the time this new dataset was assembled. The Centerline dataset, however, is also not of survey quality, meaning that the limitations described by FDOT should be similarly applied to all information in this dataset.LiDAR DEMs contain vertical error in raw point cloud elevations and additional horizontal error when transposed into raster cells. Regional differences in MHHW provide another source of error. For all these reasons, inundation predictions for road segments should only be used for general planning purposes and not for site-level engineering or design decisions.
idinfo.datacred: Jason M. Evans, PhD, Stetson University, Department of Environmental Science and Studies; University of Georgia, Carl Vinson Institute of Government; Monroe County, Florida; Florida Department of Transportation; University of Florida, GeoPlan Center
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.2.3552

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Roadway ID - A unique 8-character identification number assigned to a roadway or section of a roadway either On or Off the State Highway System for which information is maintained in the Department's Roadway Characteristics Inventory (RCI).

attrdomv.udom: 8-character ID, the first two characters are the county code, the next 3 are the section code, and final 3 characters are the subsection code.
